item.title: Little Tommy
item.description: We are given a 32-bit binary called little_tommy: Arch: i386-32-little RELRO: Partial RELRO Stack: No canary found NX: NX enabled PIE: No PIE (0x8048000) We do not have the C source code, but we can obtain a decompiled source code using a reverse engineering tool like Ghidra. This is the main function: void main() { int iVar1; int iVar2; size_t sVar3; int in_GS_OFFSET; char local_114[256]; undefined4 local_14; undefined *puStack16; puStack16 = &stack0x00000004; local_14 = *(undefined4 *) (in_GS_OFFSET + 0x14); puts("

item.title: ropme
item.description: We are given a 64-bit binary called ropme: Arch: amd64-64-little RELRO: Partial RELRO Stack: No canary found NX: NX enabled PIE: No PIE (0x400000) We can use Ghidra to analyze the binary and look at the decompiled source code in C: int main() { char local_48[64]; puts("ROP me outside, how \'about dah?"); fflush(stdout); fgets(local_48, 500, stdin); return 0; } The binary is vulnerable to Buffer Overflow since there is a variable called local_48 that has 64 bytes assigned as buffer, but the program is reading up to 500 bytes from stdin and storing the data into local_48, overflowing the reserved buffer if the size of the input data is greater than 64 bytes.
